column5: >Hi Tom, >>I just happen to call what we do "power jigging" what I'm >refering to is popping 3/8 - 1/2oz jigs off the bottom while >back trolling. Back trolling is not legal in northern >Wisconsin but it's fair game in Canada and works like a >charm. I've simple stayed with the heavier jigs while >vertical or drift jigging in WI and my numbers have jumped. >>Jigger1 I'm kind of a novice; what's backtrolling?
What type jig head do most of you guys use. Round, stand up, or something else? Thanks
I've found the round style works well for most everything.Fred

I use round heads. Since I began power jigging with heavier jigs (3/8 Â– 1/2oz) in Canada, I started using heavier jigs on my Wisconsin trips and find the control greatly outweighs the finesse aspect of lighter jigs. My numbers have soared.

I use what is called an asprin jig. It is round but has two flat sides to it. Foil eyes can be added to the flat sides. Paul Jenesen from Wisconsin makes great jigs. You can upgrade to better hooks, guaranteed no paint in the holes and very reasonably priced. His web site is [email protected]. Give him a try.
Sorry Ross, that was his e-mail address. Here is his web site http://www.angelfire.com/biz2/jighead/index.html

Hi Jigger,I just have to ask ... what is "power jiggin"??? I vertical jig and have been for 8 years now. (I started fishing in 1993. Bad knees = quit softball and snow skiing. Back back = quit golf. Brain not gone far enough yet to start ice fishing, however!)

Hi Tom,I just happen to call what we do "power jigging" what I'm refering to is popping 3/8 - 1/2oz jigs off the bottom while back trolling. Back trolling is not legal in northern Wisconsin but it's fair game in Canada and works like a charm. I've simple stayed with the heavier jigs while vertical or drift jigging in WI and my numbers have jumped.Jigger1

I mostly use 1/4 oz. stand up jigs when fishing canadian shield lakes. With the eye in the front and a flat bottom, they slide over the cabbage weeds and when trollin or casting. (A tip picked up at a Spence Petros seminar 15 years ago.) Yea, they can get snagged if you let then sink to the bottom, but those rocky bottoms will eat any jig. Black jig with a yellow or chartruse (double) twister tail works for me.

90% of the time I jig for walleyes 1/4 - 3/8 oz, actualy had my best results with a plain lead (no paint jig)and a minnow, no tail.Question...When you folks are talking about fishing jig's w/ tails, what kinda tail are you talking about?If you are fishing jig's w/ tails do you also use minnows?Sorry if this is a stupid question, thanks for the info.

Usually a tail is something like a twister tail. Sometimes something more subtle like a fuzz e grub. A twister can make small minnows look bigger, slow the drop some, add color. If the minnow with twister doesn't produce I'll usually pinch the tail off, which just leaves the plastic chunk.
